Is all this proof that for Thucydides hovojula was just any anti - tyrannical or »constitutional« form of governmentI do not think so.  Essentially,  laovojula was to him democratic as it had been to Herodotus.  We cannot connect Thucydides' laovofxia with any special political institution such as,  e.  g. ,  that of responsible government,  but neither was it to him an ovofia KaXXurtov,  On the whole,  it was little more than a fine cloak to cover any moral deformity.  »For the leaders in the States«,  Thucydides tells us in that grandiose moral denouncement of his own times ( III 82 ),  »acting from ambition and greed ( ôià nXßove^iav xal ( piXoxifiiav ) ^ using a beautiful party name by honouring either the political iaovofxia of the masses or a wise aristocracy,  made the general interests which they were serving only in name,  actually their prize«.  We understand how the disillusioned realist found a consolation in the ideal picture of Pericles' democracy.  Everybody knows that he called it Ыусо / uèv ôrjjuoxQariay êgyq ) ôè гто rov ngcorov àvÔQoç àgxv ( И 65 ).  The more general meaning of this statement is that the leading man in a State is incomparably more important than the stitution.  It will be the task of the last section of this paper to answer the question raised by such a statement with regard to the period with which we are here mainly concerned.  Thus,  I hope,  we shall discover how and when democracy — the word no less than the matter — was born in Athens. 
The Founding of Democracy
It has been a tendency among some contemporary historians to blame their predecessors for having taken political conditions and changes,  especially in earlier Athenian history,  too much as constitutional issues®^.  No doubt,  it was useful to be reminded of some of the social implications ; but It could be shown that the new interpretations had to stand up,  not only against the views taken by the Greeks of the fourth century,  but even against contemporary evidence®^.  We shall confine ourselves to the questions connected with the emergence of a democratic Athenian State,  and they practically boil down to the one well - known question : was Cleisthenes the founder of Athenian democracy?
